docs.lead_paragraph: THE pictures in Dr. David Satcher's office lean like oversized dominoes beneath a wooden table, waiting to be hung on the walls. Their owner, however, has little time for decorating these days. It has been two months since Dr. Satcher, the son of uneducated farmers from rural Alabama who rose above poverty and racism to become one of the nation's most respected doctors, was sworn in as the 16th Surgeon General of the United States. During that time, he has been working furiously, and mostly behind the scenes, to carve out an agenda to restore dignity to an office that has long been mired in controversy.

headline.main: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Dr. David Satcher; Tiptoeing Through the Mine Fields of Health Policy

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr David Satcher, new Surgeon General of United States, on his goals in office; he says he believes that Americans are most concerned about affordable health care and effects of violence and drugs on their children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Claudine Woolf, a 28-year-old Northern Californian, claims she was muscled out of her senior sales position with Mary Kay cosmetics after breast cancer and pregnancy thwarted her ability to meet a monthly $4,000-to-$8,000 sales quota. In a recently filed civil suit, Woolf says she asked the Dallas-based cosmetics giant for a brief reprieve while she endured a mastectomy, chemotherapy and childbirth. Mary Kay higher-ups allegedly rebuked her and even whistled in a tow truck to reclaim a Kay lady's prized possession: the company car, in Woolf's case a bright red Pontiac Grand Am. Mary Kay has responded with a statement that illustrates why courts are so very necessary. Curiously, they say she wasn't fired at all and retains her position.
docs.abstract: Claudine Woolf sues Mary Kay Cosmetics, holding she was pushed out of senior sales post after breast cancer and pregnancy thwarted her ability to meet monthly sales quota; company holds she was not fired and retains job (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The principal of Stuyvesant High School, one of the most prestigious public schools in the nation, has halted publication of the school newspaper indefinitely after months of infighting that pitted student editors against one another and against their faculty adviser. Those disputes were inflamed in recent weeks by a handful of articles criticizing the conduct of individual teachers and the policies of the city teachers' union. The principal's action has quickly drawn the academically selective school, which sits on the banks of the Hudson in lower Manhattan, into the murky debate over the Constitutional rights of student journalists. Although the Supreme Court ruled a decade ago that a Missouri high school could censor its student newspaper in instances in which the school's ''educational mission'' was threatened, the court provided little guidance on how to define such situations.

headline.main: Student Journalists Without a Newspaper; School Halts Publication, Raising Question of First Amendment Rights

docs.abstract: Stuyvesant High School Principal Jinx Cozzi Perullo halts publication of school newspaper indefinitely after months of infighting that pitted student editors against one another and against their faculty adviser, Daniel Coleman; disputes were inflamed by recent articles criticizing conduct of individual teachers and policies of city teachers' union; Cozzi Perullo's action has drawn academically selective school into murky debate over Constitutional rights of student journalists; photo (M)
